@nachocano Thanks, I'll merge this.

@taegeonum I did a pass. My main feedback is not to break current users with the API changes. We can file a JIRA to do that which is blocked by the 0.12 release. That way, we won't forget to delete all these deprecated APIs.
@taegeonum I did a pass. Similar to #247, we need to be careful not to break current users with this.
@markusweimer Thanks for your comments. I've addressed all of your comments. Please take a look at them.

The move of `NameClient` from class to interface does indeed break code, as `new NameClient(...)` no longer applies. Maybe we should keep it as a class for now, and then make the move to an interface once we are sure people only get the instance via Tang. Does that sound feasible?

@markusweimer I'm thinking about two different implementations of NameClient. First is DefaultNameClientImpl which lookups a remote NameServer, and Second is LocalLookupNameClientImpl which lookups a local NameServer. The interface of `NameClient` is needed in order to inject different implementation.

I've made all the tests in the `ClassHierarchyDeserializationTest` to have the Avro version separately so that we can test both versions in parallel.
This looks good. I'll test and merge.

I did a pass, which left me confused about the naming rules for static fields. In some cases, this PR changes them to be `IN_ALL_CAPS_WITH_UNDERSCORES`, in other cases it changes them to have `camelCase`. What's the rule here?

This is tricky, as changing a class to an interface creates an incompatible API. We could introduce _another_ name of the interface. How about `NameResolver`? That way, the old `NameClient` can maintain its name and implement `NameResolver` in 0.12, and it can be renamed to `RemoteNameResolver` in 0.13. What do you think?

Also: There are now merge conflicts on this PR, please resolve or maybe even rebase.

I did a pass. One thing that is confusing to me is the sheer amount of code in `AvroClassHierarchySerializer`. Wouldn't all the methods convert the given `ClassHierarchy` to the corresponding Avro types and then serialize that to `byte[]`, `string`, `file`, ...?

I'll have a look.

static final => "constant" => IN_ALL_CAPS_WITH_UNDERSCORES 
Pretty much every other kind of variable (final only, static only, both local variable and class members) =>  camelCase 

I'll re-check and make all LOGs static final.

I've done a pass over the logic of this. It seems correct, but I wonder about how we represent racks here. We basically assume that there is a fixed set of racks, and that racks are a one level hierarchy: Within each rack, there are machines and machines host containers. That isn't able to reflect certain topologies as they might come up with federated YARN clusters.

Maybe we can represent the racks and machines in a single-root namespace. For example `/rack5/machine3` or `/california-data-center/room1a/rack4/machine1`. If we allow for asterisks at the end of such a path, we can capture relaxed locality. And lists of such paths (with or without asterisks at the end) form the priority of a request.

Does this make sense?

On the code side, this employs mutable state (`allocated`) and quite a few jumps (`break`, `continue`). I wonder whether we could instead do a more functional approach: Instead of trying all racks in a loop that also performs the allocation, we could have a method in `ContainerManager` that returns the first rack with availability, given the priority list. We can then proceed with that (immutable) rack name to send an allocation.
Is there a rule against `public static` without `final`? If not, we might want to consider adding it, as static, mutable state is the root of many issues.

The comments make sense. Will do...
Just to double-check: We agreed on having the racks and machines in different namespaces right?
Let's say racks can be something like:
/dc1/rack1
/dc1/rack2
/dc2/rack1
/dc2/rack2
....
One question here. We assume a two level namespace here? /datacenter/rack? Or we should focus for a deeper one? for example /dc1/room1/rack1? Is it fine if I assume the two-level naming structure for now?
In the future we talked about having the flexibility to configure the topology and not assign machines to random racks, maybe there we can also allow the user to configure the naming directory structure...

And let's say machines names can be something like:
node-1-32131231
node-2-32131321

The user will be able to make a request with a rack name list and a node name list...
for example he can ask: /dc1/\* as the rack name list and node-1-32131231 as the node name list...
In that case we will try to get a container in that node first, if that doesn't work, we will get a container in any rack in dc1...
Makes sense @markusweimer ?

[Reef-pull-request-windows #476](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows/476/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

> One question here. We assume a two level namespace here? /datacenter/rack? Or we should focus for a deeper one?

I believe we don't have to make any assumption here. In the end, we do a prefix match anyhow, right? In which case the number of `/` in the rack name shouldn't matter.

> The user will be able to make a request with a rack name list and a node name list...
> for example he can ask: /dc1/\* as the rack name list and node-1-32131231 as the node name list...
> In that case we will try to get a container in that node first, if that doesn't work, we will get a container in any rack in dc1...

Yes. If the user gives a node name, that should take precedence over racks. All node names are tried before resolving to use the rack name list.

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #634](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/634/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

Check for static without final looks like this one http://api.dpml.net/checkstyle/3.5/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/j2ee/FinalStaticCheck.html, but it seems to not be part of standard checkstyle. I'll look into whether we can enable it for our code.
Add it as a JIRA to the bottom of the list. For now, we need to have the Hadoop checkstyle pass :-)
